H0.text: when did they start adding zinc to pennies. 1864

H1.text: when did they start adding zinc to pennies. 1873

H2.text: when did they start adding zinc to pennies. 1880

H3.text: when did they start adding zinc to pennies. 1943

A4.text: In 1943, zinc-coated steel cents were made for a short time because of war demands for copper.

A5.text: United States cents minted after 1982 have been zinc with copper plating.

A6.text: Zinc is a major component of U.S. pennies minted after mid-1982.

A7.text: Zinc toxicity is mostly in the form of the ingestion of U.S. pennies minted after 1982.

A8.text: The mass and composition of the cent changed to the current copper-plated zinc core in 1982.

A9.text: Cents minted from 1944 to 1946 were made from salvaged WWII ammunition shells, making a special brass composition to replace the steel cents, but still save material for the war effort, and are more common in circulation than their 1943 counterparts.

A10.text: One reported case of chronic ingestion of 425 pennies (over 1 kg of zinc) resulted in death due to gastrointestinal bacterial and fungal sepsis.

A11.text: In 1994, 33,200 tonnes (36,600 short tons) of zinc were used to produce 13.6 billion pennies in the United States.
